response.answer_text: I know for a fact that some teachers don’t love students. Students can be self absorbed, noisy, demanding, lazy, irresponsible, and persistent to the point of being completely annoying. However, despite those properties, students are above all inexperienced little kids. They play more than they work. Teachers know this and most teachers love their students. If we are talking about primary and secondary levels (below college and university levels), teachers are highly overworked and underpaid and despite the saying (if you can’t do, teach) most teachers actually can do something better. They teach because they like teaching and because they love the students and worry about them. For university level (which is my case), this is not the case. Teaching at a university is much more than just teaching. Actually for professors teaching is only a part of their work. Moreover, they are much better paid and rewarded for their work. Hence it is not the students that make them teach. Nonetheless, they are still normal human beings and more often than not, they love their students. Believe it or not, even the self absorbed, demanding, and annoying ones. We’re actually more annoyed at the fact that they don’t live up to their potential than anything else.

Yes, Wholeheartedly ! How much we teachers love our students? Parents deal college and universities once in a semester or only on teacher-parent meetings or even not at all. We deal with all the ups and downs to make sure our students get what they deserves.Parents expend part of their life earning to child, we teachers expend our time and effort i.e. Life indirectly for betterment of our students.Teachers are the one to track progress, make personal connection so that they can give advices and help students to be better person everyday.At the end of the semester teachers are the one to keep eye on result and mark sheets rather than parents. Teachers are one to visit university websites first to get their students' result.We become happy on students achievements and sad on not meeting expectations. Inspiring and filling up failed student with “I Can” attitude is not a joke. Even parents nowadays don't care these stuffs.People nowadays see teachers as paid slaves who exchange their time for money. But you'll realize what it needed to be a responsible teacher only by being one. You need courage, discipline, hard-work, fresh contents, knowledge transfer and communication skills along with constant energy level throughout the day.  Without loving your students, it's not possible to be a good teacher. Thank you. Image: BusyTeacher

Yes teachers love their students.. As a teacher I also love my students..  I teach tuitions. Being a teacher I really enjoy their company. They are just awesome. They keep me refreshed all the time. They always make me laugh. If someday I'm not in good mood, they keep trying to make me laugh. They share their daily  school experience. We together laugh. I also feel rejuvenated whenever they talk about school. And I just go back in flashback, to my school life. I share my experience with them. Even on Sundays I take tuitions.  Now as tomorrow is teachers day so the 12th class students are preparing something for their teachers. They share with me - "didi we are preparing this today,that today." Etc etc... One my student is wearing a saree. She used to discuss daily  - "didi am going to wear this saree or that saree.." Finally yesterday she decided on the saree.. I really enjoy when they discuss everything.. With me..  I love  them.. :)

Thanks for the A2A. I can only speak for myself. I love some students; most of them I like just fine; occasionally, I get students who are creepy or whom I dislike for various reasons. But all my students have the opportunity to be in the “loved” category until they demonstrate themselves to be unworthy of that. For the record, I teach adults, not children. And I’m a fallible human being, not a bodhisattva or saint or some such. Teachers love teaching and seeing the “lights come on” in their students’ eyes when they see real learning and curiosity in action. Teachers also love learning; sometimes what we learn is how to be more generous and compassionate to our students.

Yes,Teachers love students and students love teachers...I am student and I feel really lucky to be loved by many teachers. Guru and student relationship is a very deep one.  He not only teaches the subject but also about the way to live a life.  There is always an unconscious interaction between a teacher and a student.  The primary goal of a teacher is to "transfer" his knowledge on a topic to his students successfully.  If the student has successfully transferred the knowledge then that would be the "happiest" moment for the guru.   Guru starts loving the student when he comes to know that he is paving his path using the small knowledge (knowledge can be anything not just subjects) which he taught.Guru is like a person who sows a seed and tries his level best to grow it into a plant and then to a tree which can bear fruits.  He loves those fruits a lot and he praises himself looking at the tree growing much bigger and bigger. My HOD (Mr. S.P.Singh) always says this, "I scold you'll! I am concerned about you'll, not because I am an HOD but I feel you'll as my children."I am really happy and lucky to have such people as my gurus I am thankful to you for asking this question.  You just bought back few memories.

As I am writing this, I am a junior in high school taking Early Childhood Education classes at school. I am not a teacher yet but I plan to so I will tell you from my point of view as a student. Yes of course, your teachers love you. They love that you come everyday into their classrooms ready to learn, ready to become better citizens. Teachers are always there when you need to talk or when you are going through a rough situation. Teachers like to listen to their students whether it is something academic or personal and try to find ways to help them. In my opinion, teachers are like your second parents. If you are a middle or high school teacher, they have so many students and responsibilities that they don’t really have much time to interact with each student one on one (and of course there are boundaries when it comes to a teacher-student relationship) My point is that even though teachers have a lot of work to do and you might feel like they don’t like you, they definitely do. They like to watch you grow up and accomplish a lot of amazing things. Hope this helps! Sending love 💕 ~Joyce Ps: also, go follow these great people, they will definitely give you a great insight into the teaching field Annabelle Clark Jennifer Kohos Kostiner Kenny Olsen

Answering “Do teachers love students?” Thanks for the A2A. Yes, many of us do have a high regard, a warm affection, for our students as a whole. I call it love, a semi-parental love, though nowhere near as strong as that for individuals. I don’t know how teachers manage to stay teachers if they don’t have that. Of course there are some students who annoy me, generally because they disrupt the class and make it harder for other students to learn. But that doesn’t mean I don’t feel the same affection for them as for the others.

Mostly, I think, because they’re students themselves. Teachers love to learn, and love to share what they’ve learned with others. Around students teachers are constantly learning and growing. Of all the classes my partner teaches, my favorite is cultural diversity. It’s a mandatory class - all students have to take it and most resent the hell out of it. Each one of them thinks that it’s the dumbest idea for a class they can imagine, and besides they already know what cultural diversity means! So in the first three weeks of class she goes over what the terms mean, like discrimination and stereotype. She lets them warm up to the idea that they all know what discrimination means, because each student in the class is the ONLY person there who’s ever experienced it firsthand! And then the magic starts. As they go through the different types everyone in the class suddenly realizes that not only have they experienced discrimination, but so has every other person there. And that most of them stereotype, so they’re dishing out as much as they receive, without ever realizing it. By the end of the class my partner will receive long letters of thanks. In a journey of just a few months, lives changed. New understanding was gained. I remember one in particular, written by a woman in her 60’s. She confessed that her own mother taught her how to hate people, and she passed the lesson on to her children. She thought it might be too late for her daughter, but maybe not for the grandchildren. She was going to spend the rest of her life trying to teach those kids not to hate. And with every story, my partner learns even more. About people. About the world. About things that separate us and bring us together again. Let me tell you something. Teaching is the greatest job in the world! It’s such a shame no one can make a living doing it. :(

I certainly hope so. It has been my experience. What could be a better profession than one in which you loved the others involved? I write about this issue in most all of my answers in the area of teaching and my life experiences. If anyone considers teaching a drudge, or students consumers or, worse, products, please do not join the profession. If anyone hates young people, they should never be allowed anywhere near a school. Actually, if you are a Christian, you are required to love your students. I never considered any other feeling towards my students than love. Did I fail to practice it? Did I make mistakes? Did I ever say anything wrong? Yes, I did. Did I ever want to hurt a student? No, never. Was I prepared to spend my life to aid them? Yes. Was I prepared to risk injury for them? Yes. Did I believe with all my mind and heart that I would die to protect them? I did.

I often feel honoured by the fact that my students listen to me and try to answer the questions I pose. I was not a good student myself until after I was expelled from school, and then became curious enough to study on my own accord. I know that there are many things that a teenager would prefer to do than to learn the concepts and facts that I teach. I also know that in all likelihood much of what I teach them will not serve them in their adult life, and that many of them will forget most of what I teach them, unless they pursue some field of study and a career that relates to my subject. I also think that humanity is constantly evolving; and that my students belong to a generation which will be in many ways better than the generations before them _ including mine. My students will inherit the world after I’m gone, and they are therefore the most important things in the world. This world and it’s future belongs to them. They have the potential to do much greater things than I. They are also filled with hope and enthusiasm, which brightens my day. For these reasons, I love my students. I may feel greater love for some, but I don’t think I have disliked any. I may have been lucky with my students; but this has been my experience so far.

Of course we love the kids we teach I love the collective community as a group and seeing students learn how to self regulate during reading and writing workshop . I have fond memories of teaching 10 years ago (wow I just realized I’m pretty old. And of course there are super memorable kids because you shared a special connection. I am happy that I can find something I love in each of the kids I work with right now (elementary the best).

response.answer_text: Some teachers love their students. I think that all the good teachers I know, at least like their students. Students do not always realise that their teachers love them, because we often make them do things they don’t want to. They would rather play around, we insist that they focus on the lesson. We do this because we care about them, although they may not see it that way.

Mike, do you have children? It's hard not to love all your children, especially since you are with them for 10 straight months. You develop relationships with your kids in that time. They become a piece of you. I have taught thousands of students, and I can tell you about every little person I have encountered.

A2A How would we be teachers without them? Teaching requires students. They are central to our identity as people who love to teach. Some of them bring extra challenges and require us to dig deeper into our expertise on both student characteristics and teaching methods. Some of them are so intelligent and creative that they take us to new understandings as we work together and bring us to new levels. Both the challenging and the enlightening make us better teachers and in a sense allow us to be their students as well. Symbiosis.

If you count the hours, you will find that students spend more time with their teachers than with their parents. So, tutors play a big role in their everyday life. If teachers do not love their pupils, I do not think that the students will have a good time at school.
